results.headline: The Broad Scope of Broadway
results.summary_short: The documentary “ShowBusiness” makes one marvel at the stamina of artists who devote themselves to a world of many miseries and few rewards.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of ShowBusiness: The Road to Broadway

results.headline: Cutting Hair and Cutting Remarks
results.summary_short: Written and directed by Mark Brown, “The Salon” is a battlefield of finger-snapping, head-thrusting attitude.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Salon

results.headline: Beats With a Meaning
results.summary_short: Giving “inspirational” a good name, Matt Ruskin’s vibrant and soulful documentary “The Hip Hop Project” sets its universal message to an inner-city beat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hip Hop Project

results.headline: A Sense of Purpose Takes Flight
results.summary_short: In “Duck,” Philip Baker Hall is a lonely widower who finds a purpose in life when an orphaned duckling comes his way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Duck

results.headline: The Cold Male Gaze
results.summary_short: “Casting About,” from the documentary filmmaker Barry J. Hershey, is a record of casting calls for actresses in a dramatic feature that Mr. Hershey wrote but has yet to direct.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Casting About

results.headline: Learning to Empathize With a Suicide Bomber
results.summary_short: “Day Night Day Night,” a movie about a suicide bomber, may be serious, and it is certainly sure of itself. But it is also maddeningly, purposefully evasive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Day Night Day Night

results.headline: Marks Mysterious and Foundlings Sad: O, Tangled Web!
results.summary_short: Guy Maddin’s “Brand Upon the Brain!” is a baroque entertainment with one foot in silent cinema and the other gingerly toeing the sound waves.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brand Upon the Brain!

results.headline: When Images Take on Lives of Their Own
results.summary_short: This documentary about four World Press Photo contest winners defines icon to mean a still image so searing that it supplants memories of the event it was supposed to record.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Looking for an Icon

results.headline: Negotiating a Shadow World, With Bumps
results.summary_short: In “Allegro,” the past is a shadowy night town whose geography is continually rearranging itself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Allegro

results.headline: Deadpan on Ice
results.summary_short: This debut feature by the filmmaking team of Dominique Abel, Fiona Gordon and Bruno Romy earns two adjectives that rarely go together: breezy and bold.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of L' Iceberg

results.headline: Analyzing Love
results.summary_short: “The Treatment” is a movie with its heart and head in the right place. Too bad its aesthetic sensibilities and technical coordinates are not as well situated.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Treatment

results.headline: Superhero Sandbagged
results.summary_short: If ever a movie had a case of the blues and the blahs, it’s “Spider-Man 3,” a sequel that is fizzled rather than fizzy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spider-Man 3

results.headline: From Scraps of Metal to Biking Medals
results.summary_short: “The Flying Scotsman,” which tells the story of cyclist Graeme Obree, is a conventional underdog sports movie that should have been much more gripping.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Flying Scotsman

results.headline: More Than Friends With Benefits
results.summary_short: “Race You to the Bottom,” about a pair of thoroughly unlikable 20-somethings, is self-consciously edgy and romantically limp.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Race You to the Bottom

results.headline: Paris as Cinematic Soufflé, From Quartier to Quartier and Director to Director
results.summary_short: “Paris Je T’Aime” could be described as a cinematically literate travel brochure. But the Paris we see is not so prettified that it looks and feels unreal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paris, I Love You

results.headline: The Poker’s High Stakes, the Couple’s in Love and the City Is Mostly Sin-Free
results.summary_short: Even though “Lucky You” is sometimes dull and generally thin, there is something winning about the movie’s genial lack of ambition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucky You

results.headline: Paranoia in a New Age
results.summary_short: The vivid sense of time and place is the best thing about the initially promising, ultimately irritating psychological thriller “Civic Duty.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Civic Duty

results.headline: He Vanished. (Whether He Actually Existed Is Another Story.)
results.summary_short: “Missing Victor Pellerin” is an enigmatic and utterly compelling story of incinerated art, unbridled egos and exotic plants.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Missing Victor Pellerin

results.headline: Secrets in the Snow
results.summary_short: Let us give thanks for what “Wind Chill” largely is: a moody, spooky tale, rendered with laudable economy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wind Chill

results.headline: Breaking for Laughs
results.summary_short: “Kickin’ It Old School” is actually much more amusing than it has a right to be, considering that you know exactly what’s coming.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kickin' It Old Skool
